document.text: You cant keep a good man down. A good example of this old adage is Bob Jamerson. Jamerson, known around Appomattox as the retired Jamerson of Jamerson and Sons, and a local history buff, isnt about to let a physical handicap keep him from serving his community. He has committed himself to collect for the Cancer Crusade, which will kick off in Appomattox County next month. Jamerson will use an Amigo battery-powered vehicle to make his rounds during the cancer-fund drive. The 78-pound, 18-inch-side vehicle will be a common sight the next few weeks around Walton Place, where Jamerson and his wife, Vicky live, and where Bob has agreed to collect for the cancer drive. While the Amigo may not ever show up in the Indy 500 - - its speed hovers around 3 miles per hour - - it is nonetheless a reliable source of transportation. Ive always wanted to do something like this, says Jamerson. yhen I was young, I always wanted a paper route. This vehicle is nice because it gives me the mobility to get around, and collect for the cancer crusade. Jamerson will be one of 50 volunteers collecting in the Appomat tox area.. Marge Mims and Beck Hudson are co-chairmen for the crusade. Other chairmen include memorial chairman, - Mary Alma Hudson business chairman, Mrs. June Chenault Mr. and Mrs. W. C. Dudley

document.text: Yesterday morning at oclock, the home of Mr Mrs. M. C. Smith was the scene of a pretty marriage, when their daughter, Miss Frances Amelia, became the bride of Mr. Rolanc Walton Jamerson. The parlor was beautifully decorated with ferns and cut flowers. Just be fore the ceremony At Dawn ing was rendered on the violin by Hon. J. R. Horseley, with piano accompaniment by Mrs. C W. Smith. The couple enterec the parlor to the strains of Lohengrins Wedding March, and stood under an arch of sweet peas, where they were met by Rev. D. G. Trent, the pastor of the bride, who officiated in a very impressive manner, the ring ceremony being used, dur ing which O Promise Me was played softly on the Piano. The bride was attired in a beautiful costume of New Blue Chiffon Crepe, with accessories to match, and carried an arm bouquet of Butterfly Roses and was at tended by Miss Emily Harvey Immediately after the ceremony, the happy couple left for an auto tour through the Valley of Va., and will visit Hagerstown and Baltimore, Md., Washington, D. C., Richmond, Va., and other points of interest before return ing. They will be at home here after July 4th. The bride, who is a steno grapher employed in the Clerks 05ce, is one of the popular girls of our town, takes an active interest in church, community, and social affairs, and has many friends here. The groom is a prosperous young business man, and has been a valued employee of the Ould-Lawson Hardware Co., for the past several years. Our best wishes go with this young couple.

document.text: Yes, it is possible for the Town of Appomattox to lose the Court Street project. The Town of Appomattox, approximately five years ago, made initial plans for the Court Street project to include reconstruction complete with curb and guttering and sidewalks. To acquire the necessary property, 44 parcels of land were involved. The town has acquired 43 of the 44 parcels. The one remaining parcel, the one holding up the entire project, is that owned .y Jamerson  King Realty Company.

A. rules will govern play except as amended by local club rules. Scorers are not required, however, all play ers in each foursome shall at test the scores by signing the score card before turning it in at the starters tent. Winter rules shall apply which permits improving lies in the fairways only approx. 12 in. and not in any rough or hazard. Out of Bounds areas are identified with the white markers and the la goon on hole No. 9. Since the course will be closed to normal play at 1100 a.m. these three 3 days, all members are urged to come out and participate, helping to make this a Super Tournament . In order that tournament play is not delayed, all participants must be on their assigned start ing tees no later than 1225 p.m. on all three 3 days and every one is asked not to practice on the greens prior to play thus reserving the best possible con ditions for actual play. If ad ditional information is needed, please contact your tournament committee H. W. Conner, G.H. Jamerson, Tony Gutherie or Floyd Fleshman, Jr. In case of rain, the tourna ment will be played the follow ing weekend, Sept. 11  12 and it will consist of 36 holes in stead of 54, with flights deter mined after the first 18 holes are completed.

document.text: Whatever ehance Appomattox County had of going through 1955 without a highway fatality, went glimmering about midnight Satur day. It was undoubtedly one of the worst car wrecks in the history of the county, two youn me met in stant death and two others remain in critical condition, following the crashing of a speeding car over an embankment and into a tree about four miles this side of Bent Creek on Route 26. The dead Cecil Howell -Stephens, 26, of Route 2, Gladstone, and Raymond Edward Jamerson, 29. also of Route 2, Gladstone. At latest reports, two other occu pants of the death car were still un conscious and in a very critical con dition at a Lynchburg hospital. They are Carl Bryant, 19, and Calvin Phelps, 28, both of Route 2, Gladstone. It is understood that Bryant and Phelps have fractures of the skull and leg. The death car plunged over the left side of Route 26, dopvn an em bankment and literally wrapped it self around a tree. The ear jack knifed, badly mangling the victims. After the car was prized from the tree, and brought to Appomattox Sunday morning, large crowds gath ered all during the day to view the wreckage. Other crowds drove to the wreck site on Route 26. State Police who investigated the crash, declared that high speed was the obvious cause of the wreck. These deaths started Appomattox County off into 1955 with no chance of bettering its 1954 highway death toll. Last vear there was only one highway death in the county, and that, too, occurred in January. In 1953. the county also had only one highway death.

document.text: ,-What are the goals for the Junior Chapter of the FHA The Jr. Chapter of the Future Homemakers of America pre sented two skits to emphasize their goals for 1976-77 at their monthly meeting, Oct. 22nd. Sharon Taylor, Jr. Chapter president presided. Jayne Doss, 2nd Vice President presented the skits. The first skit was on the goal Improving Personality traits. Chapter members in this skit were Karen Johnson, Marilyn Ran dolph, Debbie Hamlet, Judy Martin, Margaret Moore, Cyn thia Goode  Vicki Moser. The 2nd skit was on the goal Learning to Understand and Get Along With Others. In this skit were Jayne Doss,Cheryl Walton, Gina Adams, Sue Price, and Judy Jamerson. The topic for the years program is Its A Big World - Get Ready. . The programs for the year are October 22, Skits on goals. document.text: Weight Watchers To Have Dinner Meeting The Appomattox Weight Watchers Class will hold a din ner meeting on Monday evening. Sept. 25, at the Parkway Rest aurant. Class procedures will begin at 645 and dinner will be served at 730. All members and free Lifetime Members are in vited to attend. Members may bring one guest, v The cost of the dinner will be 2.25 per person. Please make reservations with Mrs. W. E. Jamerson or Mrs. Gerald Blanks prior to Sat., Sept. 23.
